div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: GERMANY AS THE WORLD POWER.
div.p: Germany will, it appears, be rather isolated at the coming conference, and the forward policy of the Kaiser in regard to Morocco has, we are told to-day in a telegram from Rome,, even excited the antagonism of the Press of Italy, which is quite secondarily in- terested in the fate of Morocco compared with England, France, and Spain. In fact, throughout the Bourses of the world there is a very anxious feeling as to the part which the Kaiser intends to play. The uneasiness caused by the German Emperor’s policy is due to the fact that he represents a nation which is very strong on land, so that none Pf its neighbours would care to quarrel with it, which is creating a great Navy, and which; as its statesmen have preached to its people, thinks itself entitled to a fall share of the good things of this world, among them trade, ship- ping, and colonies. If Germany has set her heart upon anything the nation that stands in her way mast be very strong and courageous, or mast be discreet enough to star.d aside and be polite. For the Germans have been brought up for several generations on the Prussian doctrine, which is that of Philip and Alex- ander and of the Roman republic—that if a nation thinks a thing right it mast be strong enough to make it so. They have had occasion to observe that what seems to one nation righteousness sometimes seems to, another na- tion to be wrong, and that when the two views come to be argued out the logic employed is that of force.. They are naturally anxious that righteousness as they see it should prevail, and for that end they rend their young men to barracks their boys .to training sqaudrons. The result is that the Gorman nation has a certain consciousness of power. The effect upon the national character is like that of athletic training upon some men we have seen, who are perhaps not always as tactful. as some of their less muscular friends. The German notion of policy is expressed by the word Realpolitik, which means policy that deals with the world as it island eschews sentiment. Now we venture to suggest that in all these German charac teriatics there is a good- deal of practical wisdom Ivy no means out of place in a world of which we are told that the principle is the struggle for existence and the survival of the fittest, but at the same time each charac- teristics do not make for confidenoe in the dur- ability of peace in Europe, especially at such a moment as the present.

Of course the jealousy we feel in regard to Germany's recent policy in Morocco and elsewhere is historically quite justifiable, for Great Britain mast necessarily oppose the state, which desires to have a preponderance in Europe. But it mast be confessed that Ger- many is equally justified in her policy. What would German policy naturally be? The Ger- man Empire was created int 1871 by the perpetual federation of twenty-six German States, some of which had long been among the independent Monarchal of Europe. The Empire has a population of fifty-six millions, so that there are more Germans in Germany than there are white men in the British Empire. A State like the German Empire cannot exist without patriotism, and what should we expect to be the natural idea of every patriotic German? Sorely he will want Germany to flourish and be powerful and to have as much influence in the world as she can possibly get. His nation is civilised. It does a fair share of the world’s work in literature, science, and art, in industry and trade, and in all that belongs to national life. Its army has proved itself second to none. Its people are as well acquainted with geography and' history as any other, perhaps better than any other. The German may very well ask himself—Why should Germany be second to any other Power ? What answer can be. given him? Where is he to look for,4he answer? Probably to history, in which he has had excellent instructors, for though England boasts of Gibbon, that great historian wrote in the century before last, and his work ends with, the year 1453. Since then the Germans have had Ranke, who has written for them the history of German}, of France, and of England, as well as the history of the world. Moreover, while every Englishman buys Gibbon, few read him, but a great many Germans read Ranke. What, then, is the lesson of history, the question to which our hypothe-. tical German seeks an answer? Perhaps, first of all, that unity is strength. Well, the Germans have united and are fifty-six millions; what next ? Perhaps that a nation should not grow lazy and neglect the arts of war. The German feels that his country is sound on that point, for every man is trained to arms, and German generals within his time or his fathers; defeated all the generals or Austria and of France. Perhaps that sea power gives a Commanding influence in the world-, and that sea power rests on trade and a mercantile marine. Very good; Germany is cultivating her trade and her mercantile marine, is sedulously applying her military experience to the creation of a great Navy, and is picking' up coaling stations'-' as fast as opportunity offers. Why should Germany not be as much entitle 1 as any other Power . to compete for the first place in the world b . These are the questions which an Englishman has to answer before ha should complain of German ambition.

Th-to arc other questions which perhaps an Englishman, and certainly a British statesman, may pat to himself. On what ground are the forty-one million British of Great Britain and the ten or twelve more millions of Greater . Britain ‘entitled to expect to retain for their ' . country the pre-eminence in the world which they believe it has acquired? History shows that there have quite a number of Empires, including vast territories, compact or scattered resting on land power or on sea power. None of them has hitherto been permanent; why should the British Empire have a title to long dura tion? What plea can the British advance which would rightly bar the ambition of Ger- nany to be a very great Power in the world?

div.head: THE POLITICAL OUTLOOK: GREATLY IMPROVED FEARS ABOUT MOROCCO DISSIPATED.
div.p: ( Gazette’s Special Service. )
London, Friday, Jan, 12.

The official and popular assurances which have been made in Germany and elsewhere have dissipated the fears which had been entertained concerning the outcome of the Morocco Conference. Russia’s loan of eleven millions from the French bankers and the im- proved condition of that country have caused tho general political outlook to be greatly improved.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail via Port Said and Brindisi will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Egyptian Institute.
div.p: There will be a meeting of the Egyptian Institute at 3.30p.m. on Monday next, 15th inst. Dr. Apostolides will lecture on the linguistic and ethnological relations of the Pelasgians, Hellenes, and Albanians.

div.head: Army Inspection.

British Chamber of Commerce.

The January number of the monthly journal Of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt has just made its appearance, and in yester- day's issue we published an excellent article from this journal on the subject of credits in Egypt The other contents are as interesting as usual.

div.head: The Aboukir Mosque.
div.p: This morning the foundation stone of the minaret of the Aboukir Mosque, which is being erected through the liberality of Mr. Geo. B. Alderson, was laid. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, and a number of native notables were present ,at this interesting ceremony.

div.head: National Hotel.
div.p: The small dance at the National Hotel, Cairo, was a great success and was - attended by a fashionable crowd. Among the many well- known persons present was Prince Mahmoud Hamdy Pasha,uncle of the Khedive. Mr. Bauer, the energetic and popular manager of this hotel, deserve! ;to be congratulated on such a successful social function.

div.head: Attempted Suicide.
div.p: Yesterday a young Greek girl, sixteen years of age, of the Attain quarter of Alexandria, tried to commit suicide by throwing herself from a window of her parents’ house into the street, because she was not allowed to marry the man of her choice. She broke her left leg and received other serious injuries in her fall, but is exacted to survive.
Sailors and Soldiers’ Institute.

An attractive entertainment has been arran- ged for Monday, 13th inst., at 8.30 p.m., the greater number of the performers being from "H.M.S. Minerva. The programme, which includes songs, readings, banjo duets, and cornet solos, will be further enriched by piano selections and songs from Mrs. Gordon and Mrs. C. A. Wilson. Admission will be free.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lady Beatrice Thynne is staying at the British Agency.
The Hon. Evelyn Baring’s conditions shows a remarkable improvement.
Sir Elwin Palmer, we are glad to hear, is now convalescent and hopes to return to work in a few days’time.

M. Suzanne, president of the tribunal of Toulon, has been proposed by the French Government as judge of the Alexandria Mixed Courts. M. Suzanne is Mayor - of Fuveau, Bounches du Rhone, and is a strong Republican in his sympathies.
Lieutenant Grogan, R.N., of the Coast Guard Administration, is about to be trans- ferred from Alexandria to Port Said
Mr. Kenneth Speir has left for England to engage the services of new railway officials.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON.
div.p: OPENS with fedora: SIGRA BELLINCIONI’S SUCCESS.

Our Cairo Correspondent telephones: The Cairo opera season began with Fedora last night. Fedora is rather a good introduction to an opera season ; the “book” is fairly modern and not uninteresting of its kind The music is midway between a reminiscent of Wagner and Verdi on one side and Puccini on the- other, and the house is or was last night— fall, well dressed, and quiet. The whole per- formance centred on Signs. Bellincioni, who proved herself to be all- that we had heard or expected of her,—a most admirable artiste with a delightful voice, sympathetic' in the highest degree from beginning to end. We are. indeed lucky to have the honour of hearing her in Cairo, and we shall look forward most eagerly to her appear- ance in the other operas. Traviata, for ex- ample, is a part which she plays us few can play it—in a word, she is an event in the history of Cairo opera. The rest? Well the list of names and programme synopsis would serve at a pinch to make an extra paragraph. They are much the same as usual so far. Sig. Polese appeared here for the second time and his voice seems rather stronger than last year. He was distinctly (good as the french diplomatic. Signs. Zeppeli was graceful and clever as Countess Olga. The tenor, as Loris,-well, it would-be wisest to hold one’s hand and cease criticism herewith.

S-ASIDE COMPETITION.

The committee of the Egyptian State Railway institute Football Club announce that a 5-aside football competition, for gold and silver medals, presented by Mr. F. H. Trevi- thick, will take place on the Institute ground at Geziret Badrane, commencing at 2 p m. un the 6th and 7th February, for bona-fide football clubs only.

Military entrants must be company teams only, whose entrance application must be accompanied by a certificate signed by the company’s officer, stating that each player entered has been in the company at least three months.

div.head: DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS THE DIRECTORS REPORT. SUCCESSFUL YEAR'S WORKING.
div.p: The following is the text of the report of the directors of the Egyptian Delta Light Rail- ways, Limited, for the year ended 30th Sep- tember, 1905, which in to be presented to the proprietors at the eighth ordinary general meeting, held on Thursday, 21st December, 1905, and adjourned to Tuesday, 30th inst., at Winchester House, Old- Broad street, London.

Lines Opened to Traffic.—At the ,30th September, 1904, 830 kilometres (say 516 miles) were open for traffic. During the year 25 additional kilometres have been opened, making a total of 855 kilometres (say 531 mile), to which must be added a further 40 kilometres (say 25 miles) taken over from the Metropolitan and Cairo Helcuan Railway, making a grand total of 895 kilometres (say 556 miles) open at 30th September, 1905, as under:

Working Expenses.—The ratio of working expenses to gross earnings has in or eased on the Delta Railways to 61.15, owing to heavy repairs and renewals. The percentage of expen- ses to earnings on the whole undertaking was 61.31.

DIVIDEND.—The net earnings, for the year from all -sources are £79.642 19s. 4d., as shewn by the net revenue account, which with the interest earned, £2,334 17s. lid., the ba- lance of profit transferred from the Helouan Railway, £8,026 5s. 10d., and £2,055 5s. 2d. brought forward from 1904, amounts to £92,059 5s 3d. A ter payment of the interest on. debentures and providing for the sinking funds for the redemption of the debenture and bare capital, reserve funds, &, a balance of £41,258 0s. lid. remains, of which an interim dividend paid in June, 1905, absorbed £17,108 Os. 0d., and the payment, under agreement, of accrued dividend of 5 per cent on the 111,030 Preference shares issued in purchase of the Helouan Railway £5,651 10s. Od., leaving a balance of £18.598 10s. 11d. available for divi- dend. The board now recommend the payment of a further dividend of 2 per cent. on the Pre- ference share capital, making a total of 4 per cent, for the year, which will absorb £17.425 8s. 10d., leaving a balance of £1.173 2s. 1d. to be carried forward. -

Cairo Lime Stone Quarries. -The work upon this section has not progressed as rapidly as was anticipated, owing to delays caused by local contractors. It is hoped that part of the lines will be completed, and ready for working by the end of the year

Metropolitan and Cairo Helouan Rail- way.—Formal sanction for the taking over of this line was obtained from the Government in December, 1904. The directors are pleased to state that since that date the Government has consented to a modification of the terms of the concession, covering this section of line, by extending the date upon which Government has the option of purchasing the line by al period of 25 years to April, 1927. The traffic receipts from this section’ of line have proved satisfactory, and when the contemplated im- provements and additions to the rolling-stock are effected, similar results are anticipated. Under the o’d statutes of the Helouan Rail- way, power was given to set aside a special, reserve, before Government participated in the profits, subject to such special reserve being formally authorised at a general meeting of the shareholders of the company. In 1904 this formality was omitted by the old Holouan Company, and it is-therefore, at the request of the'Government, necessary to pass a formal re solution authorising the retting aside, to a 1 special reserve, of the sum of LE. 2.412,780 of the monies taken over from the Helouan Rail- way by this company. A resolution to this effect will be submitted to the meeting.

Menoufieh Concession-Official Govern- ment sanction for extensions in the Menoufreh Province, which it was hoped would be granted In the beginning of 1905. has not yet teen re ceived, negotiations with Government, in con- nection with the terms of certain clauses in the draft concession having caused delay. Terms have been discussed with the Light Railway Commission, official confirmation of which by the Government iB awaited.' Pending the Battlement of the terms of the concession mate- rial for the construction of 60 miles of line has been purchased and shipped to Egypt so that work may be immediately commenced when official sanction has been received:

New Capital.—In view of the outlay neces sitated on the Helouan Railway and also for the construction of new lines in the Menoufieh, Province and for the purchase of adequate rolling stock to cope with the increasing traffic, an issue of 18,538 5 1/2 per cent. Comulative Preference Shares of £'0 each was made to May. 1905, pro rata to the exiting share- holders at a premium of £2 10 0 per share. A farther issue of £10,000 4% Debentures at par has also been made.

Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company.—In January, 1905, this company increased its authorized share capital to £250,000 by the creation of an additional 150,000 Ordinary shares of £1 each, of which, in May, 1905, 100,000 shares were issued pro rata to the shareholders at the price of £2 per share. The 10,000 shares to which this company was entitled were taken up.

Alteration of Financial Year.— As the present financial year, of the Company closes during the busiest season of the year it is considered advisable to alter the date from the 30th September to 31st March. It is proposed therefore, to issue a report and statement of accounts in June next for the half year ending 31st March, 1906, after which the report and statement of accounts will be issued annually,

Resignation of Directors. — The directors have with much regret to report the resignation of Lieut-Col. E.L. Marryat, R.E., to whose energies and experience the company is very largely indebted for its successful development since its incorporation in 1898.
Directors — Sir Elwin PalmerK K.C.B,, K.C.M.G. Baron Jacques de Menasce, and Mr. Robert Miller retire by rotation, and being eligible, offer themselves for re-eleotion.
Auditors — The Proprietors will be asked to elect Auditors for the coming year. Messrs. F. Davies Meredith and Co., being eligible, offer themselves for re-election.

Between the Bristish Consulate and Turf Club.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS. THE ANNUAL REPORT. HOPEFUL OUTLOOK FOR. FUTURE.
div.p: The sixth annual report of the directors of the Egyptian Cotton Mills, Limited, will be. presented to the shareholders at the seventh ordinary general meeting, to be held at Winchester Home, Old Broad street, London, on Thursday, the 25th inst. The following is the text of the report The directors submit herewith the balance sheet and profit and loss account of the com- pany for the year ending 30th September, 1905, duly audited and certified. They regret to announce the death during the summer of their chairman, Mr. Isidor Ellbogen, of Paris. His place has not yet been filled. You will remember that at the last annual meeting,' which took place very late, in April a second or additional report-to that made up at- 30th- September, 1904, was read, which gave the position of your undertaking up to date That additional report was of a very gloomy nature, the outlook at that time causing your directors considerable uneasiness. In May, however, your affairs began to look considerably brighter, and from then to the dosing of this financial year we have had a very successful run, which altered the final results completely, as will be seen from a perusal of the accompanying balance sheet.

Your directors, wish to draw your, attention to the following point, that, whereas the profit on manufacture last year was £992 10s 3d., this year it is as much as £14,409 6s. 10d. This increase has been brought about by the good margins we have Obtained between the cost of raw cotton and the sale price of our goods, con- sequent, to a large extent; upon the great wave ‘ of prosperity in the cotton trade, which bene- fited us during the last five months and caused a very good demand for our cloth and yarns, and also by the considerable' reduction in the cost of manufacture on previous years, owing to the increase in the output of the mill. Your directors, since the closing of the books, have arranged to suppress the selling agency which up to the present has been so expensive to your company, and in its place have appointed a salaried salesman.' They are confident that this course will effect a consider- able saving to the company in the future, without in any way reducing its volume of sales. No depreciation has been written off the : plant and machinery, but your directors consider that the considerable increase in the value of your land since its purchase may be regarded as in some measure a set-off against the depreciation that has' taken place on. the remainder of your property since commencing work. The goods made at the mill have greatly improved in quality and sell easily and well. In conclusion; your directors feel that your company has now weathered a critical period ; in its exigence, and that, given ordinary, conditions of trade, the outlook for the future in considerably more hopeful.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISERS NOTE.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette, Sir, -I happened to take up a copy, of the 'Egyptian Gazette,’’ with the Financial Ad- viser’s Note, which is very interesting to people in this country. I think, however, that a word to calm the fears which the Financial Adviser seems to have in reference to the excess of imports over exports would not be out of place. Taking the figures as they stand, it would not be at all surprising if this differ- ence consisted entirely of profit, but in any case a disparity cf this kind need give rise to no uneasiness. This suggestion that "we are paying for our imports with capital provided by the foreign investor" is very far fetched, and to judge by the Adviser’s subsequent artiole it would appear as if the foreign in- vestor, who is no doubt an essential, and is both beneficial and useful in a country of rapid development, was a sort of bogey haunting his thoughts even "in cathedra.”

Comparison of the imports and exports in the United Kingdom and the United States, for example, show enormous differences, which can only be accounted for in the most round- about way. The truth that 'every import demandds an export and vice versa is very illusory. It is highly probable that in the present case the profits arising from trade are mere wanted in specie than in any other form, and the figures would point to the country being somewhat bare of precious metals. If you care to insert this letter, I think it might be worth while doing so — Yours truly,
Scrutator.
London, E.C., 5th January 1906.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—Apropos of the Note, I may mention that there is one passage that has caused some surprise in Alexandria. The author therein states that it is time to do something for the third class passenger on the railways, and not only for the first class passenger and the alien merchant prince. Now, in the first place, I understand that this way of speaking of our local merchants has not been highly appre- ciated in our town, and it seems to me not to be particularly good taste to refer to such an important class in such a facetious strain. After all the Alexandrian merchants are an important class in this country and it is a pity to entitle them in such terms.— I am, etc. Enquirer.
Alexandria. 11th January.

div.head: JAPANESE PRISONERS. A TALK WITH AN OFFICER.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Wednesday.

On Sunday evening the last batch of Ja panese prisoners pawed through Port Said en route for Yokohama, Maji, and Kobe, under the command of Cols. Mizagushi and Yoshikawa, late of Kuroki’s forces. In con- versation with one of the Japanese officers, many of whom, by the way, seem to be better acquainted with German than English, I learned that they were all very delighted to return to Japan. Contrary, however, to other reports, they expressed themselves as fairly well satisfied with their treatment. They especially spoke well of the courteous behaviour of Russian officers with whom they had been associated. There also seemed no desire on the part of any of them either to disparage their late, enemies or to mini' mize the fact that they considered it might have been more satisfactory to have fought out the war to a finish, instead. of conclud- ing a peace in which, from a diplomatic point of view, Russia gained her one and only victory in the straggle.

div.head: French Troops for the East.
div.p: On Saturday evening the Euphrates, a new ship of the Messageries Line, reached Port-Said on her first voyage to Saigon, having one hundred and eleven soldiers on board. The French seem to be strengthening their gar risons out in their East Indian possessions, probably for the same reason that the Ame- ricans are increasing their forces in Manila, owing to the increasing importance of the East as a possible sphere of action, and to be within easy reach of China.
Accession Day.

On Monday morning the Governor's resi dence here, the Consulates, and chief banks and shipping houses in the town, were gay with bunting in honour of the 12th anni- versary of the accession of the Khedive. H.M.S. Diana was also decorated. The bat- tery of the Coast Guards fired a salute of 21 guns. Mustafa Ibadi Pasha, supported by Khalil Bey Riad, Sub Governor, and Schalk Bey, held a reception, attended by the Consuls, chief Government officials, and eading residents.
Distinguished Passengers
Among the passengers of the P. & 0. Isis this morning were Lady Beatrice Thynne, sister of Lady Cromer, and Lady Grazhill
Russian Cruisers
Three more Russian cruisers, the Aurora, Oleg, and Almuz, some of the survivors of this naval warfare in the East, are expected here within the next few days.
The S.S. Balmoral has been refloated, and is at present being overhauled for repairs at Suez before coming through the Canal.
Notable Arrivals.

Among the passengers of the N.D.L Zaiten was his Excellency Wang Ta-Sick,. Special Envoy and Minister Plenipotentiary to the Court of St. James, together with his wife and daughter and a large retinue:
Seventy-five tourists, including the Bishop of Hereford, arrived here by the P. & O. Egypt.
Yachting.
The. yacht Evena, en route for Bombay, with- Mr. H. J. Mason on board, passed through Port Said on Monday. Yesterday the yacht Victoria, owned by Mr. Nicholson, left for Australia.
Russian Prisoners.

Contacts for the repatriation, of 30,000 Russian prisoners have- been given to the North German Lloyd, the Russian Volunteer Fleet, the Hamburg line of Hey and Gerhard, Ham- burg, and the Eastern Asiatic, of Copenhagen, The Hamburg- Amerika Line and the Dominion Line, of Liverpool, are also in treaty with the Russian Government.
British Transports.
The trooping season is now in full swing. The Ionian passed through yesterday with 1,500 rank and file, whilst the Sicilia came from Kurrachee with 1,170 for Southampton.
Import of Hashish.
Strong measures are being taken to put down the importation of hashish, by the infliction of corporal punishment as well as fines and im- prisonment.
Seizing Obscene Literature.

Those residents and passengers who have protested from time to time, in season and out, against the selling of obscene literature and photographs, -a large trade in which seems to have been done at Port Said,—will be pleased to hear that the police have seized large consignments of these, it is to be hoped they will also prohibit the display of the cards which disgrace some of the windows of the chief thoroughfares of the town. Port Said not many years ago had a by no means enviable notoriety in this respect. Of late, however, it is pleasing to note that owing to the watch- falness of the authorities, the trade seems to be confined to a few only, who so far have escaped the vigilance of the police.
Disorderly Houses.

Measures are also being taken to regulate the houses reputed not to be quite orderly in the town, and it is probable that shortly many of these places will be abolished. The old stories of people having to come ashore here "armed to the teeth,’’ were decidedly exagger- ated, if not absolute concoctions of passengers- and sailors. As a matter of fact for many years now Port Said has been one of the most orderly and best regulated ports in the Medi terranean.

div.head: ELECTION CAMPAIGN. ACTIVE AND HEATED. “C.B.” RETURNED UNOPPOSED.
div.p: London, January 11.

The campaign continues to be most active and most heated. Sir Henry Campbell-Ban- nerman spoke at Liverpool, Cheater, Wrexham, and-Shrewsbury, being shouted down at the latter place by a group of youths cheering Mr. Chamberlain and singing the National Anthem.

Mr. Lyttelton was unable to speak at Leamington on account of the uproar. Speaking at two meetings at Manchester. Mr. Balfour severely criticised scandalous leaflet which is being circulated, accusing one of his ancestors of malpractices as con- tractor for India. He described it as the lowest depth of -political meanness. Speaking at Dunbar, Mr. Haldane said that efficient army was necessary to maintain peace. (Reuter)
London, January 11.

Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has been unopposed withdrawn on account of illness. The Social Democratic Federation has issued a manifesto -to the electors of Battersea, de- nouncing Mr. John Burns as a traitor. In a proclamation, the Socialist Executive Committee advises workmen not to take part in the elections. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN NATIONAL ASSEMBLY. DELAY IN MEETING.
div.p: St. Petersburg, January 11.

The National Assembly- will not meat before the end of April. The delay is due to the preparation of new ' lists consequent on the large extension of the.suffrage. The go- vernment notifies that the meeting will then only be possible if there are leas strikes and disorders. The Conncil‘.[of the Empire, which Constitutes the Upper Honse, will consist of 176 members. (Reuter)

div.head: CHINA AND JAPAN. A SECRET AGREEMENT.
div.p: The “Daily Telegraph” learns from Tokio that a secret agreement between China and Japan precludes foreign interference concern- ing the Manchurian railway. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION. ITALIAN PRESS ANTI-GERMAN.
div.p: Rome, January 11.

A section of the Press is markedly anti- German on the subject of Morocco. The “Secolo” declares that Germany is isolated in spite of paper alliances, and can no longer diotate her despotic will to the otLer chancel- eries. (Reuter)

div.head: FRANCE AND PEACE.
div.p: Paris, January 11.

M. Doumer, on taking over the presidency, said that the Chamber would continue to group itself around the Government to aid it to emerge from the passing external difficulties. France, sure of her moral; and material strength, is resolved to maintain peace and safeguard her independence. (Havas)

div.head: FRENCH SENATE.
div.p: Paris, January-11.
M. Fallieres has been re-elected president of the French Senate. (Reuter) Paris, January 11. The Senate has elected M. Failures presi dent by 173 votes out of 249 voters. (Havas)

div.head: EGYPT’S TRADE. NOVEMBER IMPORTS.
div.p: Anyone giving a casual glance at the Customs return for November,, and comparing them with the same period last year, would be liable to arrive at the incorrect conclusion that trade during tho month in question.received a. somewhat severe check. It is true that the total imports only-amounted to L.E. 1,969,345 against L.E. 2,447,129 in 1904, the decrease being L.E. 477,784, but it the must be remembered that the clearances during November and December last year were phenomenally, heavy. About that time 'merchants arid retailers, through commission agents, apparently all thought it necessary to lay in heavy stocks, presumably on the assumption that the country would readily assimilate tho Fame. There is no doubt that in many trades the theory was a false one, and buyer's have had to curtail their purchases this year.

In November 1904 the gross imports totalled L.E. 2,447,129 against L.E. 1,652,231 Jot the same month’ the previous year, the difference being an increase of no less than L.E. 794,898. This latter sum included such substantial gains as L.E. 154,580 in cotton fabrics, L.E. 126,699 in wood, and fifteen other increases of over L.E. 15,000 each. In view of this enormous expansion, it is hardly astonishing to find that the present November figures fall considerably short of those for 1904, but the fact that they are L E. 317,114 greater than the returns for 1903 is in itself a proof that trade is not mak- ing a retrogressive movement.

Out of the 15 categories into which the whole, of the imports are divided, we find that, compared with 1904, only two of them show an increase for November viz: "Cereals” and “Chemical Products” the latter being a very minor division may practically be elimi- nated. Every other group was down, the losses ranging from L.E. 267,356 in textiles to under L.E. 1,000 in paper etc.

With the exceptions of sacks and carpets (the former due to tho requirements of the cotton season) each class under textiles was lower than last year. There is no doubt mer- chants are finding the present season a bed one for Manchester goods, though thanks to large, arrivals during February, March and April, the Customs figures for cotton fabrics only show a loss of L E. 31,481. from the 1st January. For November, however, the returns for this particular class wore L.E. 155,557 lower than in 1904 Woollen goods, which are L.E. 94,709 down on the year, lost L.E. 40,982 during the month.

The classification comprising timber, coal, furniture, etc;, had a drop of L.E. 122 743, the loss on the first named being L.E. 55 527 and on coal L.E. 57882. Duty was paid on 54,893 tons against 119796 in 1904, the decrease being thus 64903 tons.

The metal class, which showed an expansion of L. E. 110,235 for October, shared in the falling off during November to the extent of L. E. 60,192, the main contributions to this figure being. "Iron and ironwork” with a loss of L. E. 48,400 and “BrasS, copper and bronze” goods L. E. 16,553 The returns here would have been worse had it not been for a slight activity in the imports of machinery, including engine, which were up by some L.E. 24,000. No railway or tramway rolling stock was passed through the Customs during the month, whereas last year the arrivals were valued at L. E. 10,630.
The wine, liquor and oil group had a loss of L. E. 35,675, mainly due to a shrinkage of L. E. 29,117 in the petroleum figures, which showed a decrease of 138,453 cases and 1,703 tons in clearances.
The sugar imports for November were 1,733,531 kilos lower than during- the same * period in 1904, the loss in the value returns J being L. E. 54,322.

The only merchant’s for whom November produced satisfactory increases were those deal- ing in wheat, maize and flour,—though the drug and chemical trade did a larger business by L.E.(indistinguishable number) than last year. Month by month the cereal class is going ahead, and we are now L.E.(indistinguishable number)higher than last year for the period 1st January to 30th November. For the month under discussion, the wheat imports were up by 4,350,799 kilos, and floor by 3,868,470 kilos, the increased value being L.E. 33,207 and L.E. 31,833 respectively. The maize returns were higher by LE. 44,738. It is only natural when a large decrease takes place in the total returns for the country that we should have correspondingly heavy shrinkage, in Great Britain’s figures. It is, therefore, not surprising to find that, out of the gross decrease of L.E. 477,784 the home country was responsible for no less than L.E. 278,258. A perusal of the fifth column of our usual monthly statistics shows the large decreases of L.E. 155,835 in cotton fabrics, L.E. 56,968 in coal, and L E. 25,148 in woollen goods. These are pitted against increases of L.E. 7,869 in locomotives, L.E,5,991 in furniture and L.E. 3,022 in the category “Other colonial produce.”

The member who very kindly compiles our Manchester Goods Report has touched on the reason for the tremendous drop in the returns for cotton fabric, and it is;therefore unneces- sary for us to say anything on the subject. We may perhaps just mention that the imports of cotton goods during November were 1,350,641 kilos and 661,011 meters less than during the same period last year.

After Manchester goods, the heavie t diminution occurred in coal, where the values cleared were down by L.E 56,968. The figures from the 1st January for this item are now L.E. 69,667 lower for the corresponding months of 1904.
The returns for woollen fabrics suffered to the extent of L.E. 25,148 during November.

The "Iron and ironwork” figures were lower by L.E. 13,233, and “Brass Copper and bronze” goods decreased to the extent of L.E. 5,855 Under the heading -of “Instruments”, a shrinkage of L.E. 8,996 took place, after which came losses in “Jewellery’’ and ‘ Ironmongery" of L.E. 5,318 and L.E. 4,291 respectively. As regards the increases, compared with 1904, there was only one class under which the expansion was more than L.E. 5,000 viz : “Locomotives" with a gain of L.E. 7,869. The total imports of steam engines were -valued at L.E. 8,650, of which Great Britain contributed L.E. 8,361, Germany being responsible for the remaining L.E. 289.
The combined furniture returns for all countries were practially identical with those of last year, though’ England’s share was L.E. 5,991 greater. (Journal of British Chamber of Commerce).

div.head: NAVAL CONTRACTS. ALEXANDRIA
div.p: TENDERS are invited for new contracts for the supply of fresh previsions and water to his Britannic Majesty's ships at Alexandria for twelve months, from April 1, 1906.

Each article (viz., beef, mutton, vege- tables, bread, and water) must be tendered for separately, and tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm must be placed on the same form. Forms for tenders may be obtained at H.B.M. Consulate.
Sealed tenders in duplicate, made oat on these forms, will be received by H.B.M. Consul General until noon on January 31, 1906.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION. COAL
div.p: TENDERS will be received at the British Army Head Quarters, Cairo, up till 12 o’clock noon on Thursday, 18th January, 1906, for the spply of 150 tons House Coal, delivered free on Quay at Candia, Crete, not later than 31st January 1906.
Forms of Tender and all information may be obtained on application at the British Head Quarters, Cairo, and Alexandria. Envelopes containing Tenders should be ad- dressed
General Officer Commanding, Cairo, and marked on the outside “Tender for Coal, Crete.” .
The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any tender. E. R. 0. Ludlow. Lieut. Colonel. Commanding Army Service Corps in Egypt. Cairo, 11th January 1906.

div.head: The Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company, adjourned from the 21st December, 1905, will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street, in the City of London, on Tuesday, 30th January, 1906, at 3 p.m. o’clock precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Directors’ Report and Balance Sheet for the period ended 30th September, 1905, electing Directors in the place of the three retiring by rotation, appoint- ing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, declaring a Dividend, and transacting the Ordinary General Business of the Company, and also for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the following Resolution then intended to be pro- posed, that is to say:

That, in pursuance of Article 44 of tho Statutes of the Metropolitan and, Cairo-Helouan Railway, and in view of the recommendation of the Conseil d'Admi- nistration, a sum of L.E. 2412.780 out of tho profits of the Metropolitan and Cairo-Helouan Railway for- tho year ending 31st December, 1904, be placed to sepcial Reserve Fund.
Dated this 10th day of January, 1906.
By order of the Board,
F. J. HORNE,
Secretary.
211, Gresham House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C.

div.p: Il est porte a la connaissance du public que le Conseil d^Administration de la Societe a de- code de reduire de 22 % le prix de l'eau fournie aux Bornes-fontaines publiques.
En consequence, a partir du ler Janvier 1906 on pourra obtenir l’eau aux dites fontai- nes a raison de P.T-3 (trois piastres tarif) le metre cube an lieu de P.T. 3,857 payees jus- qu’ici.

Cette reduction de prix ayant ete decidee par la Societe dans le seul but d’en faire profiter les habitants de la Ville, le public est prie de veiller e ce que la dite reduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui fournissent l'eau, afin de ne pas laisser cas derniers profiler da rabais qui n’a ete cousenti qu’en faveur da public. Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 milliemes

div.head: EGYPTIAN ANTIQUITIES. BRITISH COMPETITORS.
div.p: "We hope can only that the authorities at the Treasury are aware of the, competition which is taking place in the purchase of Egyp- tian and Assyrian antiquities, and will deal liberally with the British Museum.” In these words oneof the' leading English Egyptologists, in conversation with a ‘Standard’ representative, summed up a situation which is causing some concern amongst British anti- quarians at the present moment. It is an open; secret that the museums of other countries (especially those of Germany) are running the trustees of the British Museum very hard, particularly as they are prepared to pay what a few years ago would have been considered fabulous prices for good objects. Besides this, the Egyptologist remarked, "it has become fashionable for American millionaires to give to their native towns an Egyptian museum or museums, and these institutions send out enterprising agents to Egypt who, having an abundant supply of money, snap up everything in the shape of Egyptian or Assyrian anti- quities. Certain it is that if the trustees of the British Museum are not assisted (indistinguishable) effectually than has been the case hitherto, and the objects offered to them are not pur- chased as they appear, the chance of acquiring them will be lost for ever.”

Many priceless treasures have slipped through the fingers of the British Museum for want of Treasury grants, and in the ab sence of that patriotic sentiment amongst wealthy Englishmen which is so conspicuous amongst our friends on the other side of the Atlantic. Only during the past week it has been reported on the best. authority that Mr. Rockefeller has commissioned an American Egyptologist to survey the whole of the Sudan, beginning at Khartoum, and going to the sea, and has given him the means to collect any antiquities he may meet with.

Those win remember the department of Egyptian and Assyrian antiquities in the British. Museum in the old days, during the directorship of Dr. Birch, will recollect that as acquisitions arrived they were simply damped into the museum, -and that owing to insufficiency of staff and pother reasons full use was not made of the valuable information acquired, and the objects were not.arranged any consecutive order. When the great revival of interest in Egyptian antiquities took place, however, after the Egyptian war, a flood of relics poured into the national treasure house, and the authorities of the British Museum decided to set their house in order.

With the view of making the collection valuable not only to the recondite archaeologist and antiquarian, but also as a great educa- tional institution, they inaugurated a new policy, the immediate effect of which is that each gallery, and room in the department has been overhauled in the coarse of the last 16 year? Practically every room has been fitted with new cases,and the objects are now exhibit-, ed in a manner which enables them to be seen and appreciated. They were never so well seen before. In addition to this, the trustees ordered that every object should be labelled fully, and this work has been going on steadily now for a considerable number of years. Year by year, first the Nineveh gallery, then the Nimroud gallery,- the Assyrian saloon, the Babylonian room, and the four Egyptian rooms one by one emerge from the bends of the authorities rearranged and relabelled. It has been pleasing also to note the appearance of three excellent guide books, fully illustrat- ed, relating to the antiquities exhibited in the rooms referred to.

But it is in the Egyptian Gallery, which for many years remained in the same condition, that the. change is most marked. A com- prehsnsive system of re-arrangement is here manifest. The vestibule, which was formerly a sort of storeroom for antiquities of all periods, has been emptied and refilled with cases, and has a new hut priceless collection of monu- ments of the first six dynasties of Egyptian civilisation. One may be mistaken, but one does not remember having seen anything similar to tLe finest of these objects anywhere else, except in Cairo. The Mastaba door of P-tah-mes is at once a valuable, historical, and interesting object. Walking down the gallery from north to south, a great many new objects are to be seen, and these, it is under- stood, have been acquired within the last few years. The authorities are making the re- arrangement chronologically, and in order to carry their plan out systematically they have found it necessary to practically move forward the greater number of the objects by two three bays or divisions of the gallery.

Despite the effects cf the foreigner to out bid us in the Egyptian antiquity market, it is satisfactory to observe that the acquisition of treasures by the trustees goes on steadily. And this is as it should be, for the educa- tional value of the department is considerable. The Assyrian and Babylonian objects appeal to every student in the world, and four fifths of all' the history of these two countries written in clay, is in the British Museum Unquestionably the public is getting full value for the meagre amount of money voted for the museum. The director, Sir Edward Maunde Thompson, and the keeper of the department, Dr. Wallis Budge, Are to be con- gratulated upon the success which has attend- ed their efforts to popularise the most ancient and valuable collection of antiquities in the world.

div.head: MODERN EGYPT.
div.p: "Al Moayad” says :—Egypt, as described by Herodotus and other writers after him, is a wonderful country, but the state of the Egyptian Government nowadays is much more surprising. All though it his got a very wide reputation for dealing out justice and freedom to the nation, and has obtained a great deal of praise arid thanks, the Government’ has still many serious defects. On its heads are bestowed the qualities of deities. For example, Lord Cromer is entitled the ‘Creator of Modern Egypt” and so on. The external condition of the country, is indeed bright but beyond these outward and visible signs there are many troubles and much misery, proving that the Government pays but little heed to the most essential questions. The Egyptian Go- vernment does not take as its motto.'Work for the welfare of the nation," as other Go- vernments do, and the lack of education and the wretched state of the people afford evidence that the Government does not' deserve any such praise. The British Government, which used to raise no obstacles to personal freedom, has recently decided to reject from England every foreigner who may be found unable to' supply himself with his own, needs. Why does not Egypt, which receives thousands and thousands of foreigners from every part of the world, adopt the same system! It must be noticed that the real danger which menaces Egypt is not the loss of indepen- dence, but the influx of the thousands of people who come every week to live in the alley of the Nile under the protection of the Capitulations. If this danger is not stopped by the Government the foreign elements of the population will preponderate in Egypt, overwhelm the natives, and deprive them of the comforts of life and make the present confusion worse confounded.

div.head: Exhortation to Egypt-
div.p: "AL Moayad” publishes a leading article, seven columns in length; which is the seventh of a series of articles entitled "In the Valley of Thoughts.” It purports to be signed by a native Christian but appears to have been written by a Moslem. Wd make tin following, extracts : The sons of Egypt, who, it was ex- pected, would support us in improving our present condition, have deserted us, and, think- that they are quite secure, they gave themselves up to a licentious life and spoiled, our state of society. Thus, it is no wonder if our most cherished belongings pass finally into the hands of the people of the West.

What a shame ! Do the Egyptians expect, after such behavior and such a tacit consent, to secure their own prosperity in their mother- land? O, my brethren, what excuse can you offer for yourselves? The English are human beings just as you are. Why do you neglect the land of your home while they, being surrounded by its fortunes, take the greatest interest in it? Do you think to find a better and more pros perous home ? You are diligent and intelligent, Europeans, you have been the first to study our country and learn of. our shortcomings, and so you benefit by our precious land as long as you fee us slumbering. You are wonderfully hard workers, and we are wonderfully slothful. But we are the sons of those forefathers who filled the world with wisdom and culture and who held themselves far above the potentates of the Eastern Empires and the Persian kings. Our youthful countrymen have filled their minds with the longing for vain luxury and thereby have lost precious time ; but should they begin energetically to put an end to their desperate condition; and better their understanding, the outcome would be good and they would get back what they had been losing for so long.

We clearly observe those who get their education in European languages look entirely to the countries of Europe, we can see also marry young natives wearing hats ‘a la mode' and masquerading as Europeans because they have studied the European languages much more than, their own. This class of youth can be noticed doing its utmost to adopt European habits, style, fashions, and sentiments, knowing nothing or very little of their own country and people. How can such people love their home ? He was quite right who said, "In losing your language you lose yourself.” The English are politically ruining our language with a vow to undermining our society and undoing our unity for ever. Some people, however, would say, perhaps, "How is that did not the English reform our land and beautify our capital !' Are not our people living in a glorious state of unlimited freedom, through the reforms the English have intro- duced !" Wo.reply to such questions in the affirmative, but add 'that our friends, the English, are only working for themselves. They are improving the land of Egypt for their own benefit and not for the sake of the natives, who have not there’ y advanced to any hotter state. The authority of the Go vernment being in British hands our Egyptian Ministers, who occupy the highest positions, find very little to do for the welfare of their Fatherland.

div.head: THE OLYMPIC GAMES.
div.p: The programme of sports for the next inter- national. Olympic games which are to be- held in Greece between April 22 and May 2 next, has now been published. The meeting will be under the presidency of the Crown Prince of Greece, end there is stated to be a probability that it will be graced by - the presence of the ; King of England. The foot races will range from 100 yards to the Marathon race of 26 miles. There will also be pgymnastics. lawn tennis; football, fencing, nautical spirits, shooting, and cyclist compe- titions.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents. but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit — within certain necessary limits — free discussion
A MEDICO-PHILOLOGICAL REMARK.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette:.
Honorable Sir:—Kindly oblige the author by inserting in the columns of the organ of freethought and civilisation, the "Gazette,” the following laconic, medico-phraseological remarks.

The elicited reply of the honorable medical gentlemen is only partially enlightening, to the mass in general on their decision regarding the medical practitioners’ fde. The essential part is still, unanswered, i e. to elucidate to the public the ones responsible for this deci- sion, so that those who do not wish to pay the fee decided upon, may know whom to avoid.

Nevertheless, their reply testifies to the Alexandrians and the inhabitants of Egypt in general will severely ensured the medical body of Alexandria as non-scientific . and Mammon worshippers, that tire body thus collectively by the Press and otherwise, did not all participate in these proceedings. The word "Order” from a phraseo-philolo- gical stand point of view implies a harsh mandate to enforce that upon which decision . fell. This is legible but’but to governments where the failure to comply with, or carry oat, an order, can be enforced.
In modern usage, this is limited to military spheres and districts where 'partial or complete martial law is proclaimed, such as In some of the Russian Provinces.

Civil authorities generally call “Attention” simply to what they proclaim. No one dreams of martial law proclaimed at Alexandria, for it is too well governed to have affairs leading thereto. Yet the honorable gentlemen employ the word "Order” for what they have decided. This is well instanced by the Director General of the Sanitary Dept., when he calls practitioners' "Attention" regarding antidiph- theric serum and the sporadic cases of diphthe- ria .that have already infested certain parts. He does not “Order” the doctors concerned, but merely calls their ”Attention," though there are certain laws that impose certain obligatory duties on practitioners to the State in connection with the public Health. This calling -of "Attention' inflicts penalties on those who fail to execute the caution; Yet with this, the sharp word "Order” was not used. If by the decision, is only meant the few pertaining to the honorable Society, the form of the decision as published, impressed the public and the reading world at large, with the idea that it was the mandatary of the Medical Body of Alexandria; this presumption, of course, is not entertained by the honorable gentlemen, for they are quite aware that they forgot to consult the opinion of their colleagues of the City.

When the decision was first made public, it ought to have been so formulated or phrased a9 to inform the public that 'the decision was not the ordeal of the Medical Corps of Alex andria. It is hoped that the respected gentle- men will make known to the public those who thus decided that sequent blame may not fall on the shoulders of the others who did not share this opinion.

By the elucidative answer the honorable gentleman gave, the public panic which was unfoundedly aroused, ought now to be appeased to serene tranquillity and censure no further the Medical Body, for in their last communica- tion the honorable gentlemen concerned,retract their former decision to cling to humanitarian- ism. Truly yours,
Dr. Hanna Rahmet Effendi, M A., M.C., M.D.,
(Formerly a member of the Plague Com. appointed by the Sanitary Dept. to Alexandria).

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
London, January 3.

The cruiser Minerva, Captain A. W. Way mouth, now. at Alexandria, will complete her commission with the Mediterranean Fleet in June next. She will be recommissioned for another tour of service on the station. The Egyptian drafts, the (indistinguishable) of the trooping season, will embark at Southampton on the 10th prox. for Alexandria.

Lieutenant A ‘E. F. Harris, Royal Berkshire Regiment, "has been placed on duty with the draft which the 1st Battalion is preparing to join the 2nd Battalion in Egypt. This draft, like the others, embarks on the 10th February. The cruiser Mildura was paid off at Sheer- ness on Saturday last, disarmed, and disman- tled, preparatory ”to being placed on the sale list, after dose Ion fifteen years’ service on the Australian Station.

The Admiralty, having observed that very indifferent results were obtained from the six-pounder guns during the battle practice which was carried out in the past year by torpedo-boat destroyers, has decided, with the view of giving the gun-layers more praotice during the current year, that the annual practice allowance of six-pounder ammunition, for those vessels shall be increased, from 40 to 80 rounds per gun. The attention of officers command of torpedo-boat destroyers has also been, drawn to the necessity of exercising the utmost care in carrying oat target practice, bearing in mind that the object of all such practice is training for battle, the gunnery efficiency for which is judged by the present battle practice. The Admiralty has ordered that a derailed summary of all mis- fires, delays, and failures, to fire are to be included in the report of the captain, and the attention of officers in command of flotillas has been called to the necessity of furnishing this information.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE THEATRE ZIZINIA
div.p: La troupe de Comédie 'française a débute hier soir au Zizinia par la pièce de Molièré "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme".

Il y avait peu de monde dans Ja salle, mais les loges étaient bien garnies. A peine Coquelin Cadet a-t-il fait son apparition sur la. scène qu’il a été salué par de vifs applaudissement! La pièce a été bien exécutée jusque dam ses moindres détails : ce qui frappe, en effet, do- l’abord, c'est le choix judicieux qui a été fait des éléments secondaires et l’habileté avec laquelle lès rôles ont été distribués : 'à M, Daragon, le rôle belliqueux du maître d’armes, à Al. Bayle celui plus- retors de maître de philosophie, à M. Fremont celui de maître de danse et à M. Lorain celui de maître de mu- sique. M. Monteux, que nous avons déjà eu l’occasion d’apprécier l’année dernière a é é insinuant à souhait dans le rôle de Dorante. Lis actrices out toutes été ravissantes : Mme Patry en Mme Jourdain, Mme Franqueten Dorimène, Mme Baylat en Nicole et Mme Guerraz en Lucile. Mlle Mariette Lamberti a été exquise dans la danse de là Gavotte au ler acte.

Qaant à M. Coquelin Cadet, nous n'avons guère besoin de faire valoir ses qualités, car il est universellement goûté et applaudi. Il a fort bien personnifié le bourgeois gentilhomme dat s ses manies de grandeur.

Voilà pour l’interprétation. La comédie elle- même n’a pas plu à tout le monde. Que que uns, lui trouvent l’air an peu démodé. C’est cepen- dant une-oomédie d’an genre qui ne peut vieillir, car si certains tours de phrases sont maintenant hors de mode, le thème lui-même ' reste éternel : le bourgeois gentilhomme a tou- jours existé et existera toujours.
La représentation a pris fin avec trois mono logues de Coquelin Cadet : "Salut à Molière", "l’Art d’être Moderne”, et ‘La Grenouille et le. Boeuf”. Inutile de dire que le succès a été ... bœuf.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Caire, 11 janvier.
Le taux d’escompte à Londres vient d’être diminué de £ à 3 f. Cette nouvelle réduction indique; assurément, que l’aisance monétaire continue à s’accentuer sur les marchés finan- ciers.

Le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié hier à 89 3/8. Les valeurs égyptiennes ont également clôturé à leurs cours de la veille, à la seule exception de la National Bank, qui a encore perdu & de livre à 25 1/2.

A Pans, l’action Crédit Fonder est rensei- gnée en baisse de 4 francs à 801. Pur contre, la Banque d’Athènes a haussé de 2 francs à 134. Ici, le marché des valeurs a été, ce matin encore, calme avec très peu d’affaires et des cours généralement faibles, notamment dans le compartiment des Banques.
La National a fléchi de 1/16 à 25 11/16 ; la nouvelle a baissé à 24 7/8.
L’Agricole a clôturé offerte à 9 9/16 ; là nouvelle est restée a 9 1/8.
La cassa di Sconto a perdu 3 francs à 312 ; l’action nouvelle est également tombée de 211 à' 208.
Par contre, la Banque d'Athènes a regagné 1 franc à 134.
Le Comptoir Financier et Commercial s’est maintenu entre 4 9/16 et 4 5/8.
Le Crédit Foncier a avancé de 2 francs à 804. L'obligation à lots 1886 est revenue a 333 ; la nouvelle reste à 274.
La Béhéra a fait 35 1/8.

L’Immobilière a atteint 365 pour clôturer à 359, en hausse de 4 francs sur le cours d’hier. L’Alexandria Ramleh Railway s’est inscrite à 6 7/8 acheteurs. Les Dividendes Tramway.; d’Alexandrie sont revenus a 325.
La Delta Light esc faible à 11 5/8.
L’action Agncjie da Nil a, perdu 2 francs à 248. La Wardan Estate a clôturé à 5 7/8, en baisse de 3/8.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont été offerts a 11 11/16. Les Baehler sont revenus a 3 13/16 ; les Anglo-American à 5 7/8 ; les Upper Egypt à 5 3/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates sont toujours demandés à 1 19/32; les New Egyptian s’inscrivent à 28 sh. 9. Le Trust Glymenopoulo a fait 1 3/16. Les Oasis sont à 0 7/8 ache teurs, et la and Soda à 19 sh. 9.

Suivant nos informations d’Alexandrie, la hausse qui s’est produite sur des actions du Comptoir Financier et Commercial aurait été déterminée par la nouvelle que cette Société se propose distribuer prochainement un dividende provisoire.

On annonce que la propriété dite "Batigelli Aillas” située près le Savoy Hotèl, qui avait récemment été achetée par l’Egyptiàn Estates Company, a été revendue, ces jours derniers, à un riche indigène au prix de £ 14 le mètre. Cette petite affaire laisserait un assez joli bénéfice’ à la Société.
Les cours du coton sont arrivés en baisse d’A- mérique. Le Mai a perdu 11 et l’Octobre 13 points. Le disponible continue à rester invarié à 11.75.
Les arrivages ont.été de 43,000 balles contre 28,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est également plus faible.

La baisse est attribuée an rapport des G i un ers estimant à 9,721,773 le nombre des balles égre- nées an 31 décembre dernier. Cette évaluation semblerait indiquer une récolte supérieure à 10,650,000 balles.
Ici, le Mars a ouvert, ce matin, à 15 5/8 pour cloture a 15 11/16.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd’hui à midi et demie)

Notre marché des valeurs tombe dans une inaction à peu près complète. ] Plusieurs valeurs même subissent une dé préciation notable: entre antres.' la Cassa d- Sconto qui fléchit de 213 à 207 3/4 et la Delta Light de 11 11/16 à 11 1/2 la Privilégiée et de 13 à 12 1/2 la Deferred.
Les antres .titres de banques .subissent une réaction analogue, quoique moins accentuée ;• excepté pourtant l’Agricole qui se maintient acheté au an cours de 9 17/32.
En baisse également la Building Land de 4 7/32 à 4 3/16. le Trust de 1 3/16 à 1 5/32 et la Sait and Soda de 20/3 et 19/6.
Par contre, la Brasserie des Pyramides re monte de 110 à 112.
Le. bruit court d’une prochaine -émission d’Urbaine, ainsi q-e de la fusion de cette so- ciété avec la Building Land.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
